course.subject: COMP
course.name: Competitive Programming in Cybersecurity I
course.description: Cyber-attacks mounted by malicious attackers have been creating significant damage to various companies and individuals around the globe in the recent years; cybersecurity is now a high priority consideration for the major businesses worldwide. To deepen the practical knowledge in fighting against the cybersecurity threats, cybersecurity competitions are being organized every year by various institutions and organizations. This course prepares interested students with the practical knowledge for taking part in cybersecurity contests. The course will be offered as a 0-credit course in the Fall semester. Enrolled students will learn the common topics in the first 5 weeks of the Fall, getting trained in fundamental knowledge of cybersecurity. Then they will divide into two tracks in the remainder of the Fall. One track will be concentrating on topics like binary analysis, reverse engineering, the other track will be concentrating on topics like web exploitation, cryptography, computer forensics, and other miscellaneous topics. Graded P or F.
course.exclusions: COMP 3633, COMP 4633

reviews.author: ivanwong13768
reviews.title: ONLY ENROLL IF YOU ARE INTERESTED (please trust everything that 650 said in his review)
reviews.comment_content:
This course basically teaches you how to play Capture the Flag (CTF), a kind of cybersecurity competition (as if it isn't clear enough from the course name).

For the first 2 weeks, there are basic trainings that familiarize you with basic CTF skills, including Regex, Linux commands, Python, etc. After that, the course is split in to 2 tracks, namely track A and track B, which are about different topics. Track A is about reverse and binary (pwn), while track B is about web, cryptography (crypto) and a little little little bit of forensics towards the end. Forgive me for being unable to provide detailed teaching content of each category since I don't want to be wrenched by helpers.

Us 2633 students joke about this course being a CS major speedrun, which honestly isn't very far from reality. The content is very broad and deep, so you might want to try really hard and spend a lot of time to understand them if you want to get anything more than a pass.

Little appendix about some terms (even if you don't understand them now, you will eventually understand if you enroll into this course):
Flag: a string that you need to find and submit in order 7to get scores
Reverse: reversing codes from binary files like .exe and find a correct input to get the flag
Pwn: gaining partial / full control of remote systems by exploiting unsafe codes
Web: getting private information by exploiting vulnerabilities in websites / servers
Cryptography: the cryptography you learn in 3632 and/or 4631 idk (not cryptocurrency)
Forensics: retrieving deleted / hidden information inside files
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alex is not the one who teaches, it's actually COMP 4633 students (helpers) who do their presentations and teaches us. (they are paying to teach instead of being paid to teach so please send love to your helpers if you are going to enroll in the future UwU :heart::heart::heart:) All of them tried their absolute best, and the powerpoints are very rich in content and clear enough to understand. Unfortunately, they are most likely still not enough for your homework (welcome to the world of cybersecurity), so Google is your best friend.

Lectures are conducted in zoom, and they last for 4 hours (1800-2200). A lecture is separated into 2 halves, 1800-2000 is for track A, 2000-2200 is for track B, so you don't have to attend the whole lecture. After each lecture, lecture videos will be uploaded to the course website, so you can choose to watch videos instead of attending lectures. I highly suggest attending lectures though since you can chill with other students and spam :place_of_worship: in zoom chat.

The overall lecture atmosphere is very casual and relaxing, and you can chat freely with other students, helpers and even management team members who pop out of nowhere during and after lectures. There is a discord server for the HKUST Firebird CTF team and COMP X633 series, which you are highly encouraged to join. You can easily contact other students and helpers to ask for help with in-class exercises and homework, but unless you are completely lost, they usually respond with "try harder" or one or more :blobcattryharder: emojis.
reviews.comment_grading:
The highest you can get in this course is 150%, 50% from attendance, 50% from track A and 50% from track B. You only need 60% out of 150% to pass the course so it is extremely easy to pass, but it's quite difficult to get really high scores.

For attendance, you are expected to hand in an attendance flag, which is shown in lecture videos, within 3 days after a lecture, and each flag counts 5%.

Coursework of each week counts 10%, which includes both demo-ed exercises and homework. For each week in the first 2 weeks, 10% is distributed evenly between all challenges. For each week afterwards, track A and track B each counts 5%, and the 5% is evenly distributed between all challenges in the track.

Technically, if you just want to pass, you only need to submit all attendance flags and copy some exercise flags, which don't really take much time. However, if you want to score higher, it's a completely different story. Check the workload part for details.

TL;DR:
Total 150%, Passing 60%/150% (0 cred P/F)
Attendance 50%
Basic training 20%
Track A 40%
Track B 40%

P.S.: If you are interested in 3633 or 4633, you will have to score really really big in 2633 to increase your chances to get into them, as 3633 and 4633 are invitation-based.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you want to find out how the coursework looks like, I suggest you visit the intro website and take a look at the challenges in it: https://intro.firebird.sh/challenges?

==========
"We expect a 3-credit,
COMP 4000-level workload
in this 0-credit course."
~ Alex, at the start of 2633
==========

Alex literally told us that the workload is a solid E. The old course codes for the COMP X633 series are COMP 4901_, which kind of explains the high workload of this course.

All exercises and homework are CTF challenges. For the first 2 weeks, there are 2 exercises and 3 homework each week. For the rest of the course, there are 1 exercise and 1-2 homework for each track each week. Exercise flags can usually be copied from the lecture videos, but you are mostly on your own for homework. For a CTF noob like me, the easier ones usually take me multiple hours, and the harder ones take me multiple days, so unless you are already a CTF god, don't expect yourself to be able to finish all coursework.

In short, only enroll if you are interested. And if you are interested but don't want to be like me who sacrificed all COMP 1021 lesson time for dealing with CTF, you might not want to set your goals too high in this course.

reviews.title: Don't get faked by no prerequisite, but it's fun if you know what you are doing
reviews.comment_content:
(Previous Course code COMP4901N, check out more review from there)

It's Capture the flag and only CTF.

You could get some taste by visiting https://intro.firebird.sh to get some flagsss.

Main content:
Week 1-2 (Add-drop period): Introduction to CTF. Teaching the basics of playing CTF.
(Drop it if you can't even understand first two weeks classes. It would just getting harder)

Week 3 and afterwards: More Drilled into topics and split into Track A & B
(You could attend either or one)

Track A is Pwn/Binary/Reverse
Track B is Web/Cryptography/Misc

All of those are just teaching how to solve CTF with different tools and ideas. Go visit first few lessons to know more on that.

The main content for this course is not how the teachers and course materials. It's how much you've put your passion into this course. (aka Reading hours and hours of write-ups and googling.)
